Literature Review: The ocean's biological pump plays a crucial role in the global carbon cycle, sequestering atmospheric carbon dioxide and transporting it to the deep sea. This process has significant implications for climate regulation and marine ecosystems. Over the past few decades, researchers have made substantial progress in understanding and quantifying the biological pump's mechanisms and impacts on global scales.The biological pump consists of three primary export pathways: the gravitational pump, the migrant pump, and the mixing pump. The gravitational pump, which involves the sinking of particulate organic matter (POM), has been the most extensively studied. Siegel et al. (2014) developed a novel approach to estimate global carbon export using satellite observations of net primary production and particle size distributions. Their findings suggest that approximately 6 Pg C yr^-1 is exported from the surface ocean via the gravitational pump.The migrant pump, driven by the diel vertical migration of zooplankton and fish, has gained increasing attention in recent years. Stukel et al. (2018) demonstrated that this pathway could contribute up to 20% of total carbon export in some regions. However, global estimates remain uncertain due to the challenges in quantifying migratory behavior across diverse marine ecosystems.The mixing pump, which involves the physical transport of dissolved organic carbon (DOC) to depth, has been less studied on global scales. However, Hansell et al. (2009) provided valuable insights into the distribution and cycling of DOC in the global ocean, estimating that approximately 1.9 Pg C yr^-1 is exported via this pathway.Advancements in satellite oceanography have revolutionized our ability to monitor and quantify biological pump processes on global scales. Henson et al. (2011) used satellite-derived estimates of primary production and export efficiency to assess global patterns of carbon export. Their work highlighted significant regional variability and the importance of considering ecosystem structure when estimating export fluxes.Biogeochemical modeling has also played a crucial role in improving our understanding of the biological pump. For instance, Laufkötter et al. (2016) used a multi-model approach to project changes in export production under future climate scenarios. Their results suggest that global export production may decline by up to 18% by the end of the 21st century, with significant regional variations.Despite these advancements, challenges remain in creating a comprehensive global accounting of carbon export and sequestration via the biological pump. One major obstacle is the integration of data from various observational platforms and modeling approaches. Boyd et al. (2019) emphasized the need for a more holistic approach to studying the biological pump, incorporating multiple export pathways and considering the full range of temporal and spatial scales.The development of new technologies and observational strategies has opened up exciting possibilities for improving our understanding of the biological pump. For example, Briggs et al. (2020) demonstrated the potential of autonomous biogeochemical floats to provide high-resolution, year-round measurements of particle flux in remote ocean regions. These observations can help fill critical gaps in our knowledge of seasonal and interannual variability in carbon export.Another promising avenue for research is the investigation of the biological pump's response to climate change and ocean acidification. Taucher and Oschlies (2011) used a global biogeochemical model to explore the potential impacts of ocean acidification on organic matter export and remineralization. Their results suggest that changes in carbonate chemistry could significantly alter the efficiency of the biological pump, with implications for long-term carbon sequestration.As we move forward, it is crucial to develop integrated observational and modeling frameworks that can capture the full complexity of the biological pump. This includes improving our understanding of the interactions between different export pathways, as well as the role of microbial communities in carbon cycling. Burd et al. (2016) highlighted the importance of considering the full spectrum of particle sizes and compositions when estimating carbon export, emphasizing the need for more comprehensive measurement techniques.In conclusion, while significant progress has been made in quantifying the ocean's biological pump and its carbon cycle impacts on global scales, many challenges remain. Future research should focus on integrating multiple observational approaches, improving biogeochemical models, and developing a more comprehensive understanding of the biological pump's response to environmental changes. By addressing these challenges, we can work towards creating a global accounting of carbon export and sequestration via the biological pump, ultimately improving our ability to predict and manage the ocean's role in the global carbon cycle.
